services.name: CityPulse AI
services.overview: CityPulse AI is a real-time anomaly detection and predictive maintenance platform designed for proactive city infrastructure management. By leveraging advanced AI algorithms, the system analyzes a diverse range of sensor data, including traffic flow, energy consumption, water pressure, air quality, and citizen complaints, to identify anomalies and forecast potential infrastructure failures. The platform provides city officials, infrastructure engineers, and emergency response teams with actionable insights, enabling them to preemptively address issues, reduce maintenance costs, improve service uptime, enhance citizen safety, and optimize resource allocation. CityPulse AI moves beyond reactive responses to infrastructure failures and citizen complaints by anticipating problems before they escalate, transforming city management from a reactive to a proactive approach. The system utilizes machine learning models trained on historical data to establish baseline patterns and detect deviations that indicate anomalies or predict future events.
problems_addressed: Reactive responses to infrastructure failures, leading to increased costs and disruptions.
Inability to proactively identify and address potential infrastructure problems before they escalate.
Inefficient resource allocation due to lack of real-time insights into city-wide operations.
Delayed response times to citizen complaints and emergency situations.
Difficulty in optimizing infrastructure performance and reducing maintenance costs.
target_users: City Managers: Responsible for overseeing city operations and resource allocation.
Infrastructure Engineers: Tasked with maintaining and improving city infrastructure.
Emergency Response Teams: Need real-time information to effectively respond to emergencies.
Data Analysts: Responsible for analyzing data to identify trends and insights.
core_features: Real-time Anomaly Detection: AI algorithms continuously analyze sensor data to identify deviations from normal patterns, indicating potential infrastructure issues. This includes threshold-based alerts and statistical anomaly detection.

Predictive Maintenance: Machine learning models forecast potential infrastructure failures based on historical data and real-time conditions, enabling preventative maintenance scheduling. This will include time-series forecasting for water pressure, energy consumption, and traffic flow.

Automated Alerting System: The system automatically alerts city officials and relevant personnel when anomalies or potential failures are detected, providing detailed information and recommended actions. This includes email, SMS, and in-app notifications.

Interactive Dashboard: A user-friendly dashboard provides a comprehensive view of city-wide infrastructure performance, including real-time sensor data, anomaly alerts, and predictive maintenance forecasts. This dashboard provides drill-down capabilities to investigate specific areas and infrastructure components.

Citizen Complaint Integration: Integrates with existing citizen complaint systems to incorporate citizen feedback into anomaly detection and predictive maintenance models. Natural language processing is used to categorize and prioritize complaints.
user_journeys: A city infrastructure engineer logs into the CityPulse AI dashboard. They view a real-time map of the city with color-coded overlays indicating potential water main breaks based on pressure sensor readings. The engineer clicks on a specific location flagged as high-risk, viewing detailed pressure sensor data and the AI's prediction of a likely break within the next 24 hours. The engineer schedules a maintenance crew to inspect and repair the water main, preventing a costly and disruptive failure.
ai_capabilities: Anomaly Detection: Isolation Forest, One-Class SVM, and autoencoders will be used for identifying unusual patterns in sensor data. The choice of model will depend on the data distribution and the type of anomalies being detected.

Predictive Maintenance: Time series forecasting models such as ARIMA, Prophet, and LSTM neural networks will be employed to predict future infrastructure failures based on historical data. Model selection will be based on accuracy and computational efficiency.
Natural Language Processing: BERT or similar transformer models will be used to analyze citizen complaints, categorize them, and identify emerging trends related to infrastructure issues.

Model Selection Notes: OpenAI models are not directly applicable here. Embeddings might be used to represent citizen complaints, enabling semantic search and categorization. Vector search can be used to find similar past incidents. Fine-tuning may be required to optimize model performance for specific infrastructure types and city conditions.

input_data_types: Water pressure sensor readings (time series data)
Energy consumption data (electricity, gas, water usage)
data_schema_recommendations: **Sensors Table:** sensor_id (UUID), sensor_type (ENUM: water_pressure, traffic, energy, air_quality), location (GEOJSON POINT), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), value (FLOAT), unit (TEXT)
**Citizen_Complaints Table:** complaint_id (UUID), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), location (GEOJSON POINT), description (TEXT), category (TEXT), sentiment (FLOAT)
**Infrastructure Table:** infrastructure_id (UUID), type (ENUM: water_main, road, power_grid), location (GEOJSON POINT), age (INTEGER), material (TEXT), last_maintenance (TIMESTAMP)
data_sources: Third-party weather data providers (e.g., AccuWeather, OpenWeatherMap)
Utility companies (energy and water consumption data)
data_requirements.privacy_and_compliance: Adhere to local and federal privacy regulations regarding the collection and use of sensor data. Ensure data anonymization and encryption to protect citizen privacy.

required_integrations: City's existing 311 system for citizen complaints.
Geographic Information System (GIS) for mapping and spatial analysis.
SCADA systems for real-time sensor data acquisition.
Email and SMS gateway for automated alerts.
Existing asset management systems for tracking infrastructure maintenance.
integration_plan.authentication_strategy: OAuth 2.0 for secure access to city systems. Implement role-based access control to restrict access to sensitive data based on user roles. Consider Clerk or Auth0 for streamlined authentication management.

technical_specifications.architecture: The system will follow a microservices architecture with distinct services for data ingestion, data processing, AI modeling, alerting, and dashboarding. An API gateway will provide a unified interface for accessing these services.

recommended_tech_stack.frontend: Next.js 14 App Router, TailwindCSS, shadcn/ui, Vercel conventions
recommended_tech_stack.backend: Node.js / Next.js server actions / Vercel serverless functions
recommended_tech_stack.database: Planetscale / Supabase / PostgreSQL with schema notes
recommended_tech_stack.storage: Supabase storage / AWS S3 / Vercel Blob
recommended_tech_stack.AI: OpenAI API (not directly used for core functionality), embeddings (for citizen complaints), vector DB (Pinecone/Supabase vectors for storing complaint embeddings)
recommended_tech_stack.APIs: REST APIs for communication between microservices and the frontend.
recommended_tech_stack.CI_CD: GitHub â†’ Vercel automatic deploy pipeline

API_design: **/sensors**: GET (retrieve sensor data), POST (ingest new sensor data)
**/complaints**: GET (retrieve citizen complaints), POST (ingest new complaint)
frontend_components: Real-time map with sensor overlays and anomaly indicators.
Interactive charts and graphs for visualizing sensor data and predictions.
Alert dashboard for managing and resolving anomalies.

deployment_instructions: **Environment Variables:** DATABASE_URL, OPENAI_API_KEY (for complaint analysis), SENSOR_API_KEY, ALERT_EMAIL_ADDRESS, ALERT_SMS_NUMBER
**Vercel Deployment:** Configure Vercel to automatically deploy from the GitHub repository. Set environment variables in Vercel settings. Define build outputs and runtime settings in vercel.json.
**Runtime Settings:** Node.js version, memory allocation, scaling parameters

pricing_strategy: SaaS subscription tiers based on the number of sensors monitored and the level of AI capabilities. Free tier for small cities with limited sensor data. Enterprise tier for large cities with advanced AI features and dedicated support.
customer_segments: Small to medium-sized cities with limited resources.
Large metropolitan areas with complex infrastructure networks.
Regional government agencies responsible for infrastructure management.

success_metrics: Improved response time to citizen complaints (minutes).
Number of anomalies detected and resolved proactively.
Accuracy of predictive maintenance forecasts (precision, recall).
User adoption and engagement with the platform (DAU, MAU).
